posts.name: Roman A.
posts.cooked:
Hello all, our team is in the process of improving our swerve code and thus we began to wonder if there was a way to implement (on  the roborio’s side) functionality similar to the “Continuous input” feature of WPILib’s PID controllers so that we can use it with the built in PID of the TalonFX motor controller?

Thanks in advance!

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: 5104 BreakerBots | Software and Additive Mfg. Lead

posts.custom_user_title: 5104 BreakerBots | Software and Additive Mfg. Lead

posts.name: Oliver
posts.cooked: There is no way to do it directly on the falcon but you can calculate what it would be on the rio if you have the current encoder reading and the desired setpoint. This is our (probably unoptimal) solution for the rotation motor on our swerve drive.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
Are you referring to this type of continuous ? No way to optimize for shortest turn and reverse motor direction if that’s what you want thus the comment.

ohowe:

no way

https://oldsite.ctr-electronics.com/downloads/api/java/html/classcom_1_1ctre_1_1phoenix_1_1motorcontrol_1_1can_1_1_talon_f_x.html image 1637×373 30.7 KB

image 1637×373 30.7 KB

image 1637×373 30.7 KB
I’m confused by the last sentence- what exactly do they mean by “move the discontinuity outside of the function range”?

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
I picked a bad example to try to understand what you meant by continuous.

You do mean that as the encoder makes one revolution it jumps from the maximum value back to the minimum value?

The TalonXXX supports that mode with the jump being between 360 to 0 or +180 to -180. If you don’t like the jump in either of those locations you can specify your own. I don’t think this applies to you, though; I should have picked a better example.

But that illustrated the limit of what a Talon can do as far as I can tell. It’s not going to calculate which way to turn; you have to do that. It does know that 0 follows 360 as the encoder turns.

Does that answer your question?

SLAB-Mr.Thomas:

The TalonXXX supports that mode with the jump being between 360 to 0 or +180 to -180. If you don’t like the jump in either of those locations you can specify your own.

Oh I get it, thanks!

SLAB-Mr.Thomas:

I don’t think this applies to you

I’m not the person who created the topic, I’m just a reader you’ll have to ask @RomanTechPlus that.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: Thanks for the correction. I lose track of what I’m doing sometimes and especially with the time zone change last Sunday (yawn). You’re here like me - learn from what others are doing.
